resources.string: VitiSmart
Test Text
Your Infestation Heat Map
Click on each pin to reveal more information.
Confirm Dates
Grape berry moth larvae are easily detected early in the season by the presence of webs in young grape clusters. The larvae live inside the webs and feed on developing berries.
Webbing in grape berry moth infested clusters early in the growing season
Photo credit: Andrew Muza, Penn State Extension

Grape berry moth larvae build webs made out of silk strands among adjacent berries. The larvae hide inside the webs before borrowing into the grape berries. Injury of grape berry moth larvae induces red discoloration in immature berries of red cultivars.
Webbing and red discoloration in grape berry moth infested clusters
Photo credit: Andrew Muza, Penn State Extension
Injure by grape berry moth larvae induces red discoloration in immature berries of red cultivars.
Discoloration of a grape berry moth infested berry
Photo credit: Andrew Muza, Penn State Extension
Brown discoloration of grape berry moth infested berries of a white cultivar.
Discoloration of a grape berry moth infested berry
Photo credit: Andrew Muza, Penn State Extension
Wounds from grape berry moth larvae facilitate the colonization of fungi in mature grapes.
Damage by grape berry moth larvae and fungi late in the growing season
Photo credit: Andrew Muza, Penn State Extension
Eggs are small (~0.6 mm in diameter) and translucent making them difficult to detect at plain sight. Eggs are laid on grape berries throughout the growing season.
Mature grape berry moth egg
Photo credit: Flor E. Acevedo, Penn State University
Upon hatch, young larvae wander on the surface of grape berries before burrowing into them. This stage of development is the most susceptible to conventional control strategies such as insecticides.
Young grape berry moth larva
Photo credit: Flor E. Acevedo, Penn State University
Mature larvae are about 10 mm long; they get out of the berries, wrap themselves into a folded piece of leaf sealed with silk and cut the leaf piece out to drop and pupate in the soil.
Fully developed grape berry moth larva
Photo credit: Jody Timer, Penn State Extension
Pupa develops on debris in the soil before the moths emerge. The grape berry moth Paralobesia viteana overwinters in the pupa stage.
Grape berry moth pupa
Photo credit: Flor E. Acevedo, Penn State University
Adults moths are small with a wingspan of 8-13 mm and are most active at dusk.
Grape berry moth adult
Photo credit: Flor E. Acevedo, Penn State University
